ticket.title: 'increment' and 'decrement' for ActiveRecord::Relation
ticket.original-body:
Hi guys,
I've added 2 new methods to ActiveRecord::Relation
http://github.com/pch/rails/commit/b9bcb52966addb714f5d634fe78f0899e4bdd9d1 http://github.com/pch/rails/commit/486b583cc753fc53dc9a979f3d55c58b36fe0fb1
Essentially, this allows for executing queries like:
@@@ UPDATE some_table SET comment_count = comment_count + 1 WHERE id = 6; @@@
@@@ Article.create(:title => "Hello", :counter => 0) Article.increment(1, :counter) @@@
ActiveRecord::Persistence#increment and #decrement need to fetch values from the database before updating them. That way, in some cases, there's a possibility of desynchronizing field value by updating it after it had been already overwritten in another request:
@@@ # counter == 0 # request 1: article = Article.find(1)
# request 2: article = Article.find(2)
#request 1: article.increment(:counter) article.save # counter == 1
#request 2: article.increment(:counter) article.save # counter == 1 @@@
Let me know what you think about it.
ticket.latest-body:
Hi guys,
I've added 2 new methods to ActiveRecord::Relation
http://github.com/pch/rails/commit/b9bcb52966addb714f5d634fe78f0899e4bdd9d1 http://github.com/pch/rails/commit/486b583cc753fc53dc9a979f3d55c58b36fe0fb1
Essentially, this allows for executing queries like:
@@@ UPDATE some_table SET comment_count = comment_count + 1 WHERE id = 6; @@@
@@@ Article.create(:title => "Hello", :counter => 0) Article.increment(1, :counter) @@@
ActiveRecord::Persistence#increment and #decrement need to fetch values from the database before updating them. That way, in some cases, there's a possibility of desynchronizing field value by updating it after it had been already overwritten in another request:
@@@ # counter == 0 # request 1: article = Article.find(1)
# request 2: article = Article.find(2)
#request 1: article.increment(:counter) article.save # counter == 1
#request 2: article.increment(:counter) article.save # counter == 1 @@@
Let me know what you think about it.
ticket.original-body-html:
Hi guys,

I've added 2 new methods to ActiveRecord::Relation

http://github.com/pch/rails/commit/b9bcb52966addb714f5d634fe78f0899...
http://github.com/pch/rails/commit/486b583cc753fc53dc9a979f3d55c58b...

Essentially, this allows for executing queries like:

UPDATE some_table SET comment_count = comment_count + 1 WHERE id = 6;

Article.create(:title => "Hello", :counter => 0)
Article.increment(1, :counter)

ActiveRecord::Persistence#increment and #decrement need to fetch values from the database before updating them. That way, in some cases, there's a possibility of desynchronizing field value by updating it after it had been already overwritten in another request:

# counter == 0
# request 1:
article = Article.find(1)

# request 2:
article = Article.find(2)

#request 1:
article.increment(:counter)
article.save # counter == 1

#request 2:
article.increment(:counter)
article.save # counter == 1

Let me know what you think about it.

version.body:
Hi guys,
I've added 2 new methods to ActiveRecord::Relation
http://github.com/pch/rails/commit/b9bcb52966addb714f5d634fe78f0899e4bdd9d1 http://github.com/pch/rails/commit/486b583cc753fc53dc9a979f3d55c58b36fe0fb1
Essentially, this allows for executing queries like:
@@@ UPDATE some_table SET comment_count = comment_count + 1 WHERE id = 6; @@@
@@@ Article.create(:title => "Hello", :counter => 0) Article.increment(1, :counter) @@@
ActiveRecord::Persistence#increment and #decrement need to fetch values from the database before updating them. That way, in some cases, there's a possibility of desynchronizing field value by updating it after it had been already overwritten in another request:
@@@ # counter == 0 # request 1: article = Article.find(1)
# request 2: article = Article.find(2)
#request 1: article.increment(:counter) article.save # counter == 1
#request 2: article.increment(:counter) article.save # counter == 1 @@@
Let me know what you think about it.
version.body-html:
Hi guys,

I've added 2 new methods to ActiveRecord::Relation

http://github.com/pch/rails/commit/b9bcb52966addb714f5d634fe78f0899...
http://github.com/pch/rails/commit/486b583cc753fc53dc9a979f3d55c58b...

Essentially, this allows for executing queries like:

UPDATE some_table SET comment_count = comment_count + 1 WHERE id = 6;

Article.create(:title => "Hello", :counter => 0)
Article.increment(1, :counter)

ActiveRecord::Persistence#increment and #decrement need to fetch values from the database before updating them. That way, in some cases, there's a possibility of desynchronizing field value by updating it after it had been already overwritten in another request:

# counter == 0
# request 1:
article = Article.find(1)

# request 2:
article = Article.find(2)

#request 1:
article.increment(:counter)
article.save # counter == 1

#request 2:
article.increment(:counter)
article.save # counter == 1

Let me know what you think about it.
version.title: 'increment' and 'decrement' for ActiveRecord::Relation

version.body:
+1
This seems like a nice addition and it'll probably keep people from executing two queries to achieve something like this. :)
version.body-html:
+1

This seems like a nice addition and it'll probably keep people from executing two queries to achieve something like this. :)
version.title: 'increment' and 'decrement' for ActiveRecord::Relation

version.body:
+1 but i think the API could be improved a bit.
How about a default column to increment/decrement, instead of being an mandatory param?
version.body-html:
+1 but i think the API could be improved a bit.

How about a default column to increment/decrement, instead of being an mandatory param?
version.title: 'increment' and 'decrement' for ActiveRecord::Relation

version.body: Please attach a patch (as a file) to this ticket.
version.body-html: Please attach a patch (as a file) to this ticket.
version.title: 'increment' and 'decrement' for ActiveRecord::Relation

version.body: I like the idea and the implementation, but I can't +1 until there's some documentation :) In particular, I think the documentation from these methods should discuss the difference from @ActiveRecord::Persistence#{increment,decrement}@, and the documentation for those methods should be modified to mention these new ones. Other than that, looks great.
version.body-html:
I like the idea and the implementation, but I can't +1 until there's some documentation :)
In particular, I think the documentation from these methods should discuss the difference from @ActiveRecord::Persistence#{increment,decrement}@, and the documentation for those methods should be modified to mention these new ones.
Other than that, looks great.
version.title: 'increment' and 'decrement' for ActiveRecord::Relation

version.body: You're right Andrea. I've updated the patch with some documentation. Let me know what you think.
version.body-html: You're right Andrea. I've updated the patch with some documentation. Let me know what you think.
version.title: 'increment' and 'decrement' for ActiveRecord::Relation

version.body:
I'm for moving attr_name as first parameter. It's more natural and intuitive order for me. Like this:
@@@ Article.decrement(:counter, 1) Article.decrement(:counter, [1, 2, 3]) @@@
What do you think?
version.body-html:
I'm for moving attr_name as first parameter. It's more natural and intuitive order for me. Like this:

Article.decrement(:counter, 1)
Article.decrement(:counter, [1, 2, 3])

What do you think?
version.title: 'increment' and 'decrement' for ActiveRecord::Relation

version.body: Łukasz Strzałkowski, the API should be the same as the one in AR::Base. Assigning to Aaron Patterson, since he's AR's BFF.
version.body-html: Łukasz Strzałkowski, the API should be the same as the one in AR::Base. Assigning to Aaron Patterson, since he's AR's BFF.
version.title: 'increment' and 'decrement' for ActiveRecord::Relation

version.body:
@Łukasz, I agree with José. Please make the api match the api in AR::Base.
Also, I don't think the ArgumentError is worth our time. It's possible there are attributes in the database that AR doesn't know about. But even if AR does know about all of the attributes, the generated SQL will fail and we get an exception raised with no extra code.
version.body-html:
@Łukasz, I agree with José. Please make the api match the api in AR::Base.

Also, I don't think the ArgumentError is worth our time. It's possible there are attributes in the database that AR doesn't know about. But even if AR does know about all of the attributes, the generated SQL will fail and we get an exception raised with no extra code.
version.title: 'increment' and 'decrement' for ActiveRecord::Relation

version.body:
@@@ Article.increment_counter(:counter, 1) Article.increment_counter(:counter, [1, 2, 3]) @@@
already exists in ActiveRecord::CounterCache. Why not just mention that in the documentation of ActiveRecord::Persistence#increment and #decrement instead of adding more methods?
version.body-html:
Article.increment_counter(:counter, 1)
  Article.increment_counter(:counter, [1, 2, 3])

already exists in ActiveRecord::CounterCache. Why not just mention that in the documentation of ActiveRecord::Persistence#increment and #decrement instead of adding more methods?
version.title: 'increment' and 'decrement' for ActiveRecord::Relation
